_header: He loses His might and waxeth wan
Subjects: love, vicissitudes of; sermons, verse in; Christ, suffering of
_description: Christ’s suffering for humankind in a Latin sermon (by John Bromyard?), dominica in passione vel in die parasceue or Amore langueo — six lines in couplets

OxfBal149.Transcription:
He lesus is myth and waxit wanHe syket as a sorfulmanAlone he
                    drawes fro compenyeAnd ever he herkenes one ys drurieLoneliche he
                    spekis to his herteFor hym he suffrus peynis smert
OxfBal149.Editions:
Woolf,  Rosemary. 
             The English Religious Lyric in the Middle Ages.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1968: 192.

OxfMagd93.Transcription:
he losys his myght and wexyth al wanhe syketh as a sorwfull
                    manAllone he drawes fro companyand euer herkenes of his
                    drewrylouely he spekes to his hertfor hym that suffred peynes
                    smerty swete yn hert for mornyng

CULKk424.Transcription:
He lost hys myȝth & wexit al wanhe sykyth as a sorwful
                    manA lone he draweth fro companyeAnd euer he herkneth afftyr hys
                    drewerylouelyche he spekyth to hys hertefor hym he suffreth paynes
                    smerte
CULKk424.Note:
Follows 1367; phrases
                    from this repeated in the Latin commentary, f. 146vb.

TCD277.Transcription:
…losys hys myht & waxys wan…syghys as a sorofull
                    man
